title: 'Mass slaughter' of Australian racehorses rocks industry
text:
A hidden camera investigation has exposed horrific abuse of racehorses at an Australian abattoir, sparking calls for government intervention and a possible ban on horse racing.

The whistelblower video, published by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, showed former racehorses being kicked, beaten, given electric shocks and killed at Meramist Abattoir.

Meramist is one of only two facilities in Australia accredited for processing and exporting horse meat, which is sold for human consumption to Europe and Asia. An estimated 500 horses a month are processed at the facility.

The distressing footage has caused a political shockwave, with at least one federal senator calling for the national government to intervene in the industry, which is usually managed by state authorities.

Meanwhile, Lee Freedman, one of Australia's most decorated horse trainers over the past 30 years, said he was “broken hearted” at the report, and suggested the future of the sport itself was at risk.

“If we don’t make real changes the court of public opinion will bury racing," he said.

The Australian horse racing industry is worth one billion dollars. ABC investigative reporter Caro Meldrum-Hanna said about 300 racehorses went through the Queensland abattoir in just 22 days. The horses had won combined prize money of almost $5 million before their owners decided they’d outlived their usefulness.
description: A hidden camera investigation has exposed horrific abuse of racehorses at an Australian abattoir, sparking calls for government intervention and a possible ban on horse racing.
